awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Educating the Workforce in Cyber & Smart Manufacturing for Industry 4.0
awd_abstract_narration:
The fourth industrial revolution, or Industry 4.0, refers to the changes in the advanced manufacturing industry that result from application of information technologies and automation. The result is continuing growth and development of "smart manufacturing," which uses tools such as big data, advanced robotics, and virtual reality. Workers in smart manufacturing industries need new skills to keep up with the changing landscape of manufacturing operations. To help meet the needs of the skilled technician workforce in smart manufacturing, this project will develop integrated courses and hands-on labs, create a smart manufacturing certificate, and develop career maps and pathways for students to advanced manufacturing careers. Faculty will also receive training to help them stay current with the latest technologies. The project will help educate technicians who have the skills needed in the next-generation workforce and help fill the growing needs of this fourth industrial revolution.

For this project, Texas A&M University will partner with Northwest Louisiana Technical College. The goals will be to: 1) create a workforce capable of merging the manufacturing information technologies and operation technologies of cyber-enabled smart manufacturing; 2) train students in the interdisciplinary environment of Industry 4.0; 3) create pathways and career maps to assist students in completion of their education and preparation for future careers; and 4) facilitate a continuous improvement culture for faculty through professional development. This approach to technician training includes cyber-enabled, smart manufacturing processes, monitoring and control, data science, cyber-physical systems, and cloud computing to drive manufacturing operations. New courses will be developed and add-on modules will be introduced into existing curricula. These changes will enable students to expand their knowledge of communication protocols, integrated diagnostics, and analysis of scalable data. They will also enable students to work on interdisciplinary course projects that lead to a Smart Manufacturing Certificate. Industry internships and undergraduate research experiences will be incorporated into the curriculum. In addition, faculty development workshops and visiting-faculty appointments in industry will be included to enhance the ability of faculty to teach current smart manufacturing technologies and practices. Project materials, best practices, and results will be shared through the project website, professional conferences, and national organizations. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Industry 4.0 refers to the ongoing reformation of advanced manufacturing (Operating Technologies - OT) enabled by advances in automation/data (Information Technologies - IT). Often translated under the umbrella of Smart Manufacturing, it a trend in the digitization of manufacturing that converges IT and OT, thus enabling its various facets such as the industrial internet of things, big data and analytics, augmented reality, advanced robotics, additive manufacturing, cloud computing, etc. To fulfil the current and future workforce needs of industries rapidly adapting to the fourth industrial revolution, this project helped develop curricula, personnel, and communities in cyber-enabled smart manufacturing technologies.

 

As a first step, curriculum road-mapping workshops and surveys to industry stake holders (including regional Manufacturing Extension Partnership contacts, and the Occupational Advisory Committee partners) helped chart out the smart manufacturing workforce needs of the broader industrial base. Based on this, an integrated IT-OT curriculum outline was generated by the project team that drew on the strengths of existing curricular constituents, as well as ingredients needed for their integration. Consequently, several Special Project (SP) courses and Work-Based Learning Experience (WBLE) courses were developed and offered as part of the Industrial Instrumentation & Electrical Technology (IIET) degree program. These included courses such as ‘SP-II: Introduction to Industry 4.0’ that covered the 9 pillars of Industry 4.0 such as Big Data, Augmented Reality, Cloud Computing, Cyber-security, Internet of Things, etc. It is worth noting that this new IIET program at Northwest Louisiana Technical Community College (NLTCC), largely supported by this grant’s activities, participated in its second accreditation review by the Association of Technology, Management, & Applied Engineering (ATMAE) and received full accreditation through 2025. Additionally, several existing courses from the Information Technology (INTE) degree program were redesigned to include Industry 4.0 principles in the context of operational technology applications, e.g., INTE 2010, ‘Introduction to Server Network Infrastructure’ was redesigned to include Industrial Internet of Things and Big Data competencies. The format and flexibility of these courses are such that they could be integrated into short-term training, certificates or degree programs across the college.

 

The major hardware counterpart for the curricula developed is the Portable Process Training Unit (PPTU), which is a process plant trainer for fluid flow monitoring/control on which students do real-time measurement and intervention by utilizing programmable logic controller (PLC) based hardware/software. The PPTU can simulate real-world upsets to deepen student learning through the development of troubleshooting skills and using root cause analysis techniques. As part of this project, three PPTU were developed which hosted a plethora of smart sensors with remote data transfer capabilities through a cloud/network (across the three NLTCC sister campuses). These units were designed, fabricated, and put into service by existing NLTCC students from multiple disciplines and campuses. The entire process was systematically documented so that it could be used as a template for other institutions to upgrade their similar units. Further, a Mobile STEM Lab (training center) was acquired and outfitted with relevant peripherals for offsite training at various high schools to deliver Industry 4.0 oriented training and learning activities.

 

The elaborate process of conceptual design, fabrication, documentation, and deployment of the PPTU in making them Industry 4.0 compatible provided invaluable interdisciplinary learning experiences to the team of faculty and students who came together from multiple IT-OT degree programs across the three NLTCC campuses. Additionally, numerous students participated in WBLE internships relevant to Industry 4.0 as well as in 10-week NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) projects during summers; such streams of 2-year students gaining NSF-REU experiences is expected to continue beyond the duration of this project. Further, NLTCC faculty engaged in several professional development activities pertinent to Industry 4.0. For instance, 14 faculty members participated in special training involving building circuits, integrating robotics, coding to control kinematics/movement and troubleshooting; the course modeled project-based pedagogy and the integration of e-Notebook documentation into research and project management. The Arduino electronic kits and coding resources received as part of this training were integrated into project-based learning activities as well.

 

Surveying the pool of students, faculty, administrators, and local industry stakeholders that were directly touched by the project showed positive gains in terms of gaining the knowledge and skills needed for operating in an Industry 4.0 environment. Beyond the project duration, the faculty at NLTCC will continue to build on the lessons learned from the curriculum road mapping activities, continue to develop courses and the PPTU, and facilitate career pathways for students and professional development for faculty. Altogether, this project has helped to bring together and integrate the two traditionally siloed fields of information technology (IT) and operational technology (OT) in the context of workforce development for smart manufacturing and is expected to generate an empowered workforce well-rooted in smart manufacturing technologies, and capable of operating in Industry 4.0 environments.
